title: Percentages
text:
Previously, when working out percentages of amounts, we would use a method called “chunking”. For example, to find 35% of 120, we might do something like: \[\begin{align*}
100\% &= 120 \\
10\% &= 12 \\
5\% &= 6 \\
20\% &= 24 \\
35\% &= 20\% + 10\% + 5\% \\
&= 24 + 12 + 6 \\
&= 42
\end{align*}\]
This is a good non-calculator method, but with a calculator there is a far better way.

title: Percentages
text:
Previously, when working out percentages of amounts, we would use a method called “chunking”. For example, to find 35% of 120, we might do something like: \[\begin{align*}
100\% &= 120 \\
10\% &= 12 \\
5\% &= 6 \\
20\% &= 24 \\
35\% &= 20\% + 10\% + 5\% \\
&= 24 + 12 + 6 \\
&= 42
\end{align*}\]
This is a good non-calculator method, but with a calculator there is a far better way.

title: Percentages
text:
Decimal Multipliers
The key concept of this topic is the idea of decimal multipliers. In short, when we represent percentages (or percentage changes) as decimals, we can multiply to work things out.
It turns out that in many cases this makes questions much easier, particularly when it comes to compound percentage changes.
To see how well they work and how much they can simplify percentage problems, let’s look at an example.

title: Percentages
text:
Example: Pocket Money
You get £10 a week pocket money. Unfortunately, you get a little lazy about revising for your maths exam, and so you don’t score as well as you could have if you’d worked harder. Your parents are concerned, and so they decide to reduce your pocket money by 10% until your results improve.
You pull up your socks and study hard for the next maths exam, and your score is much better. As a reward your parents increase your pocket money by 10%. \[
100\% - 10\% + 10\% = 100\%
\] All good then! Are you happy with the result?

In fact this logic is incorrect, because the two 10%s are not 10% of the same amount. \[
\textsterling 10 \xrightarrow{-10\%} \textsterling 9 \xrightarrow{+10\%} \textsterling 9.90
\]
Percentage changes do not add up.
However, they do multiply. Let’s see.

\[
10\% \text{ increase} = 100\% + 10\% = 110\% = \dfrac{110}{100} = 1.1
\] \[
10\% \text{ decrease} = 100\% - 10\% = 90\% = \dfrac{90}{100} = 0.9
\] \[
\textsterling 10 \times 1.1 \times 0.9 = \textsterling 9.90
\] The decimal multipliers give the correct result.
This is the key to this whole topic. Percentages do not add up, but they do multiply.
This way of calculating percentages is important in several areas of applied mathematics, particularly financial mathematics.

title: Percentages
section: Example: Finding a Percentage of an Amount
text:
Example: Finding a Percentage of an Amount
To find a percentage of an amount, we simply convert the percentage to a decimal and multiply it by the amount.
Calculate 13% of 300: \[
300 \times 0.13 = 39
\] Calculate 87% of 400: \[
400 \times 0.87 = 348
\]

title: Percentages
text:
Test Your Understanding
Calculate the following. You must use a decimal multiplier.Please show your working by writing down the calculation. You may use a calculator.

84% of 15
9% of 78
70% of 33.2
150% of 13
317% of 2.8
84.2% of 68

title: Percentages
text:
Example: Percentage Increase
Video: Percentage Increase and Decrease
When you increase something by a percentage, you keep the original 100% and add on an additional percentage. Therefore to calculate the decimal multiplier we add on to 100%.
Increase 170 by 10%: \(\quad 170 \xrightarrow[\times 1.1]{100\%+10\% = 110\%} 187\)
Increase 40 by 12%: \(\quad 40 \xrightarrow[\times 1.12]{100\% + 12\% = 112\%} 44.8\)






Note



This way of representing percentage changes on an arrow is useful, particularly for reverse percentage changes (coming up soon).

title: Percentages
text:
Example: Percentage Decrease
When you decrease something by a percentage, you take the original 100% and remove a percentage. Therefore to calculate the decimal multiplier we subtract from 100%.
Decrease 86 by 61%: \[
86 \xrightarrow[\times 0.39]{100\%-61\% = 39\%} 33.54
\]

title: Percentages
text:
Test Your Understanding
Calculate the following. You must use decimal multipliers and write down your calculations.

Find 62% of 97
Find 3% of 52.8
Find 14.7% of 44
Find 178% of 52
Increase 24 by 9%
Increase 5.2 by 64%
Decrease 97 by 38%
Decrease 540 by 8.7%

title: Percentages
text:
Example: Reverse Percentage Changes
Video: Reverse Percentage Change
The price of an item was increased by 20% to £66. What was the original price before the increase? We can use the same arrow method as before: \[
? \xrightarrow[\times 1.2]{100\% + 20\% = 120\%} 66
\] The answer is then found by dividing by the multiplier: \(66 \div 1.2 = 79.2\)






What Not To Do




Don’t find 20% of £66. The 20% is a percentage of the original unknown amount.
Don’t use a decimal multiplier of 0.8. Reversing an increase is not the same as a decrease.

title: Percentages
text:
Example: Reverse Percentage Decrease
The price of an item in a sale was reduced by 18% to a new price of £60.68. What was the price before the sale? \[
? \xrightarrow[\times 0.82]{100\% - 18\% = 82\%} \textsterling 60.68
\] \[
\textsterling 60.68 \div 0.82 = \textsterling 74
\]

title: Percentages
text:
Test Your Understanding
Find the original value. You must divide by a decimal multiplier.

A number was increased by 64% to give a new value of 60.68. Find the original value.
A number was decreased by 23% to give a new value of 37.73. Find the original value.
A number was decreased by 6.3% to give a new value of 76,834. Find the original value.
A number was increased by 104% to give a new value of 142.8. Find the original value.

title: Percentages
text:
Example: Compound Percentage Change
Video: Compound Changes
Matthias invests £100 in a savings account at 2% interest. How much does he have at the end of year 1, year 2, and year 3?
\[\begin{align*}
\text{Year 1: } &\textsterling 100 \times 1.02 = \textsterling 102 \\
\text{Year 2: } &\textsterling 102 \times 1.02 = \textsterling 104.04 \\
\text{Year 3: } &\textsterling 104.04 \times 1.02 = \textsterling 106.12 \\
\end{align*}\]
Notice here that we are simply repeatedly multiplying by the same decimal multiplier.

Matthew invests £3000 in a savings account with an interest rate of 3.2%. How much will he have after six years? \[
100\% + 3.2\% = 103.2\% = 1.032
\] \[
\textsterling 3000 \xrightarrow{\times 1.032} \xrightarrow{\times 1.032} \xrightarrow{\times 1.032} \xrightarrow{\times 1.032} \xrightarrow{\times 1.032} \xrightarrow{\times 1.032}\ ?
\] Once we notice that we are multiplying repeatedly, we can simplify this method using powers: \[
\textsterling 3000 \xrightarrow{\times 1.032^6} \textsterling 3624.09
\]






Note



Amounts of money should always be rounded to the nearest penny or cent, i.e. to two decimal places.

title: Percentages
text:
Example: Compound Percentage Decrease
Thomas buys a new car for £15,690. The car depreciates at a rate of 4% each year. How much will it be worth in 11 years? \[
\textsterling 15690 \xrightarrow{\times 0.96^{11}} \textsterling 10013.98
\]

title: Percentages
text: Code: Compound Percentage Formula

title: Percentages
text:
Test Your Understanding

An investment of £500 grows by 4% each year. How much will it be worth after 5 years?
A rare book increases in value by 7% each year. If it is currently worth £1,200, what will it be worth in 8 years?
A car is bought for £18,000 and decreases in value by 12% each year. What will it be worth after 6 years?
A population of 250,000 increases by 2.5% each year. What will the population be after 10 years?
A laptop costs £900 and depreciates by 15% each year. What will it be worth after 4 years?
A forest area is shrinking by 1.8% each year. If its current size is 5,000 acres, what will its size be after 12 years?

title: Percentages
text:
Example: Multiple Compound Changes
Andrew buys a watch for £225. It decreased in value by 3.5% for 1 year, then decreased in value by 7.5% per year for 2 years. Find the new value of the watch.
Again this is a case where decimal multipliers make this much easier. \[\begin{align*}
3.5\% \text{ decrease} &= 0.965 \\
7.5\% \text{ decrease for 2 years} &= 0.925^2 \\
\text{new value} &= \textsterling 225 \times 0.965 \times 0.925^2 \\
&= \textsterling 185.78
\end{align*}\]

title: Percentages
text:
Example: Reverse Compound Change
Philip invests some savings into an account that pays 4% compound interest per year. After 4 years the savings are worth £17,075. How much did Philip have in the account at the beginning?
An arrow representation will be useful here: \[
?\ \xrightarrow{\times 1.04^4} \textsterling 17075
\] This shows that we should divide: \[
17075 \div 1.04^4 = 14595.78
\]

title: Percentages
text:
Example: Missing Interest Rate
Consider the same question but with a missing interest rate.
Philip invests £14,595.78 into an savings account. After 4 years the savings are worth £17,075. What was the interest rate?
In this case, we can form and solve an equation: \[\begin{align*}
14595.78 \times x^4 &= 17075 \\
x^4 &= 17075 \div 14595.78 \\
x &= \sqrt[4]{17075 \div 14595.78} \\
x &= 1.04
\end{align*}\]
which represents a 4% increase. This is the interest rate.

title: Percentages
text:
Example: Unknown Length of Time
Consider the same question but with a missing length of time.
Philip invests £14,595.78 into an savings account at an interest rate of 4%. After how many years are they worth £17,075?
There is an A-Level method called a logarithm that can help with this, but for now we will use trial and error. You can do this on your calculator to speed things up.
\[\begin{align*}
14595.78 \times 1.04 = 15,179.61 \\
14595.78 \times 1.04^2 = 15,786.80 \\
14595.78 \times 1.04^3 = 16,418.27 \\
14595.78 \times 1.04^4 = 17,075.00
\end{align*}\]

title: Percentages
text:
Test Your Understanding

The value of the house increases each year by 2.1%. How much is her house worth after 6 years?
The value of the house increases each year by 3%. How many years will it take for her house to be worth £163,909.05?
The value of the house increases each year by \(x\)% and after 3 years is worth £168,729.60. Find \(x\).
The value of the house increases each year by 14%. How many years will it take for her house price to double?

title: Percentages
text:
Answers

£169,920.47
3 years
4
6 years

Example: Fraction to Recurring Decimal
Video: Converting from a fraction to a recurring decimal
We can also do this to find a recurring decimal. For example, to find \(\frac{3}{11}\), we can do:





As soon as we get a repeated digit, we know we will be stuck in a loop, so we mark the decimal as recurring.

Sometimes there is a non-recurring decimal part before the recurrence begins:





Notice that the vertical bar only extends over the repeating part.

And sometimes it takes a long time to repeat:

title: Recurring Decimals
text:
Example: Recurring Decimal Notation
There are actually two ways to represent recurring decimals, the bar over the repeating part or a dot above the first and last digit of the repeating part, so for example, the recurring decimal \[
0.3456456456456456\ldots
\] Can be represented either as \[
0.3\overline{456}
\] or as \[
0.3\dot{4}5\dot{6}
\]

title: Recurring Decimals
text:
Test Your Understanding
Write out what each of these recurring decimals looks like:

\(0.\dot{3}\)
\(0.4\overline{3}\)
\(0.\dot{4}\dot{3}\)
\(0.1\overline{23}\)
\(0.\dot{1}2\dot{3}\)
\(0.12\overline{3}\)
\(0.4\dot{3}0\dot{3}\)

title: Recurring Decimals
text:
Example: Recurring Decimals to Fractions
Video: Recurring Decimals to Fractions
To convert \(0.\overline{54}\) to a fraction, we can use algebra. We let \(x\) equal the recurring decimal, then work out the value of \(x\) as fraction.
\[\begin{align*}
x = 0.&545454\ldots & \text{Write out the recurring decimal} \\
100x = 54.&545454\ldots & \times 100 \text{ because two recurring digits} \\
99x = &\ 54 & \text{Subtract the first line from the second} \\
x = &\ \dfrac{54}{99} = \dfrac{6}{11} & \text{Divide and simplify}
\end{align*}\]
The trick here is that the recurring decimal parts cancel out when they are subtracted.

\[\begin{align*}
x &= 0.133333\ldots & \text{Write out the recurring decimal} \\
10x &= 1.333333\ldots & \times 10 \text{ because one recurring digit} \\
9x &= 1.2 & \text{Subtract the first line from the second} \\
x &= \dfrac{1.2}{9} = \dfrac{12}{90} = \dfrac{2}{15} & \text{Divide and simplify}
\end{align*}\]






Note



Note here that when we subtract the first digit after the decimal point does not match, so we are effectively doing \(1.3-0.1\). The decimal digits after this do cancel because they are identical.



\[\begin{align*}
x   = 3&.0868686\ldots \\
100x = 308&.6868686\ldots \\
99x  = 305&.6 \\
x = \dfrac{305.6}{99} &= \dfrac{3056}{990} = \dfrac{1528}{495}
\end{align*}\]






Note



The calculation this time is \(308.6 - 3\).



\[\begin{align*}
x      = 0&.5401401401\ldots \\
1000x  = 540&.1401401401\ldots \\
999x   = 539&.6 \\
x      = \dfrac{539.6}{999} &= \dfrac{5396}{9990} = \dfrac{2698}{4995}
\end{align*}\]






Warning



Be careful here. 5 is greater than 1 so the calculation we need to do is \(540.1-0.5\).

title: Factorising with a Common Factor
section: Example: Factorising with a Common Factor
text:
Example: Factorising with a Common Factor
Video: Factorising
Factorising is the opposite of expanding. There are several methods of factorising, but the most basic one involves identifying common factors. For example, in the expression
\[
x^2 - 12x
\]
\(x\) is a common factor, and so
\[
x^2 - 12x = x(x - 12)
\]

objectID: Autumn 1/2. Factorising with a Common Factor.html#example-more-than-one-factor
href: Autumn 1/2. Factorising with a Common Factor.html#example-more-than-one-factor
title: Factorising with a Common Factor
text:
Example: More than One Factor
Sometimes, there is more than one common factor, and more than two terms:
\[
4x^2y + 8xy^2 + 4xy= 4xy(x + 2y + 1)
\]






Warning



When you take out all the factors from a term, there is a 1 left, not a 0. This is because when you factorise, you are dividing rather than subtracting, and anything divided by itself is 1.

Solving Linear Equations
Unknowns on Both Sides

title: Linear Equations
text:
Inverse Pairs
For each mathematical operation, there is an inverse operation.
\[
\Huge{\boxed{\times} \longleftrightarrow \boxed{\div}}
\] \[
\Huge{\boxed{+} \longleftrightarrow \boxed{-}}
\]
To solve equations, we use inverse pairs to isolate the variable \(x\) for which we are trying to solve.

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: One-Step Equations
To solve one-step equations, we simply use the relevant inverse pair:



\[\begin{align*}
x + 3 &= 2 \\
x + 3 - 3 &= 2-3 \\
x &= -1
\end{align*}\]
\[\begin{align*}
y-5 &= 7 \\
y-5+5 &= 7+5 \\
y &= 12
\end{align*}\]



\[\begin{align*}
3u &= 12 \\
u \times 3 \div 3 &= 12 \div 3 \\
u &= 4
\end{align*}\]
\[\begin{align*}
v \div 2 &= 8 \\
v \div 2 \times 2 &= 8 \times 2 \\
v &= 16
\end{align*}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Two-Step Equations
When there is more than one step, it’s important to think about the order of operations. Drawing a diagram can help. For the equation \[
6x-2 = 16
\] we can draw the following diagram:
\[
x \longrightarrow \boxed{\times 6} \longrightarrow \boxed{-2} \longrightarrow 16
\]
We need to work backwards using inverse pairs, so we first add 2 then divide by 6:
\[\begin{align*}
6x-2+2 &= 16+2 \\
6x &= 18 \\
x \times 6 \div 6 &= 18 \div 6 \\
x &= 3
\end{align*}\]

\[
\dfrac{x+3}{2} = 5
\] The diagram for this equation is
\[
x \longrightarrow \boxed{+3} \longrightarrow \boxed{\div 2} \longrightarrow 5
\]
We need to work backwards using inverse pairs,
\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{x+3}{2} &= 5 \\
(x+3) \div 2 \times 2 &= 5 \times 2 \\
x+3 &= 10 \\
x+3-3 &= 10-3 \\
x &= 7
\end{align*}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding
Solve these equations:

\(5x-8=27\)
\(\dfrac{x}{3}+4=9\)
\(\dfrac{x-3}{4}=1\)
\(3-2x = 7\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(5x-8=27 \Rightarrow x=7\)
\(\dfrac{x}{3}+4=9 \Rightarrow x=15\)
\(\dfrac{x-3}{4}=1 \Rightarrow x=7\)
\(3-2x = 7 \Rightarrow x=-2\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Exercise 1
Please complete the worksheet.

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Equations with Brackets
There are often two ways to solve these kinds of questions:


\[\begin{align*}
3(x+7) &= 15 \\
3x + 21 &= 15 \\
3x &= -6 \\
x &= -2
\end{align*}\]

\[\begin{align*}
3(x+7) &= 15 \\
x+7 &= 5 \\
x &= -2
\end{align*}\]


As you can see, expanding the brackets is not always the quickest method.

But sometimes if there is more than one bracket you need to expand the brackets and simplify first:
\[\begin{align*}
5(x+2)-3(x-4) &= 28 \\
5x+10-3x+12 &= 28 \\
2x+22 &= 28 \\
2x &= 6 \\
x &= 3
\end{align*}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding
Solve these equations:

\(6(x-3)+5=29\)
\(8(x+2)-3(2x-1)=39\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(6(x-3)+5=29 \Rightarrow x=7\)
\(8(x+2)-3(2x-1)=39 \Rightarrow x=10\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Exercise 2
Please complete the worksheet.

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Equations with Fractions
We can use the same method for questions like this:
\[
\dfrac{3h}{2}+3 = 12
\] The diagram and working:
\[
h \longrightarrow \boxed{\times 3} \longrightarrow \boxed{\div 2} \longrightarrow \boxed{+3} \longrightarrow 12
\]
\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{3h}{2}+3 &= 12 \\
\dfrac{3h}{2} &= 9 \\
h &= 6
\end{align*}\]

There are two methods for questions like this:


Subtract 4 first:
\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{x}{3}+4 &= 9 \\
\dfrac{x}{3} &= 5 \\
x &= 15
\end{align*}\]

Multiply by 3 first:
\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{x}{3}+4 &= 9 \\
x+12 &= 27 \\
x = 15
\end{align*}\]








Warning



When you multiply both sides by 3 you must multiply every term by 3.

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding

\(\dfrac{x}{2} - 8 = 16\)
\(\dfrac{2x}{5} + 6 = 19\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(\dfrac{x}{2} - 8 = 16 \Rightarrow x=48\)
\(\dfrac{2x}{5} + 6 = 19 \Rightarrow x=32.5\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Multiplying First
\[
\dfrac{y-5}{3} = 4
\]
In some questions, you should multiply first because of the order of operations:
\[
y \longrightarrow \boxed{-5} \longrightarrow \boxed{\div 3} \longrightarrow 4
\]
\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{y-5}{3} &= 4 \\
y - 5 &= 12 \\
y &= 17
\end{align*}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Fractions on Both Sides
If both sides of the equation are fractions, you can mutiply by the lowest common multiple of the denominators.
\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{3y+2}{3} &= \dfrac{2}{5} \\
(3y+2) \div 3 \times 15 &= 2 \div 5 \times 15 \\
(3y+2) \times 5 &= 2 \times 3 \\
15y + 10 &= 6 \\
15y &= -4 \\
y &= -\dfrac{4}{15}
\end{align*}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding

\(\dfrac{a+2}{3} = 4\)
\(\dfrac{g-4}{10} = 2\)
\(6 = \dfrac{2w+4}{3}\)
\(\dfrac{4r-3}{10} = \dfrac{1}{5}\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(\dfrac{a+2}{3} = 4 \Rightarrow a = 10\)
\(\dfrac{g-4}{10} = 2 \Rightarrow g = 24\)
\(6 = \dfrac{2w+4}{3} \Rightarrow w = 7\)
\(\dfrac{4r-3}{10} = \dfrac{1}{5} \Rightarrow r = \dfrac{5}{4}\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Variable on the Denominator
If the variable is on the denominator, the first step is always to multiply both sides of the equation by whatever the denominator is.
\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{7}{z} &= 42 \\
7 \div z \times z &= 42 \times z \\
7 &= 42z \\
7 \div 42 &= z \times 42 \div 42 \\
\dfrac{1}{6} &= z
\end{align*}\]

This same method applies even when the denominator is more complex:
\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{7}{2v+3} &= 2 \\
7 \div (2v+3) \times (2v+3) &= 2 \times (2v+3) \\
7 &= 4v + 6 \\
1 &= 4v \\
\dfrac{1}{4} &= v
\end{align*}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Comparing Methods
In some questions, there are two possible methods:


\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{2}{v}+2 &= 9\\
\dfrac{2}{v} &= 7 \\
2 &= 7v \\
\dfrac{2}{7} &= v
\end{align*}\]

\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{2}{v}+2 &= 9 \\
2 + 2v &= 9v \\
2 &= 7v \\
\dfrac{2}{7} &= v
\end{align*}\]








Warning



A very common error in the second method is to forget to multiply the 2 by \(v\). When you multiply both sides of an equation, you must multiply every term.

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding

\(3 = \dfrac{15}{y}\)
\(\dfrac{8}{3p}=12\)
\(1=\dfrac{5}{y+2}\)
\(\dfrac{3}{3a-4}=5\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(3 = \dfrac{15}{y} \Rightarrow y=5\)
\(\dfrac{8}{3p}=12 \Rightarrow p=\dfrac{2}{9}\)
\(1=\dfrac{5}{y+2} \Rightarrow y=3\)
\(\dfrac{3}{3a-4}=5 \Rightarrow a=\dfrac{23}{15}\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Exercise 3
Please complete the worksheet.

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Unknown on Both Sides
When the unknown appears on both sides, the goal is to combine those terms together so that the unknown appears only once. Then we can solve it in the same way as the previous examples. To do this, we can add or subtract one of the terms to both sides.
\[\begin{align*}
11-2x &= 6x-13 \\
11-2x+2x &= 6x-13+2x \\
11 &= 8x-13 \\
24 &= 8x \\
3 &= x
\end{align*}\]

If there are brackets, we can expand those first:
\[\begin{align*}
2(x-4) &= 6x-28 \\
2x-8 &= 6x - 28 \\
-8 &= 4x - 28 \\
20 &= 4x \\
5 &= x
\end{align*}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding
Solve these equations:

\(8-3x = 4x+22\)
\(3(x+5) = 10x + 1\)
\(4(x+5) = 3(3x-5)\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(8-3x = 4x+22 \Rightarrow x=-2\)
\(3(x+5) = 10x + 1 \Rightarrow x=2\)
\(4(x+5) = 3(3x-5) \Rightarrow x=7\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Exercise 4

title: Linear Equations
section: Example: Fractions with Unknown on Both Sides
text:
Example: Fractions with Unknown on Both Sides
When the unknown appears on both side and there is a fraction, you should start by getting rid of the fraction by multiplying both sides by the denominator:


\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{7p}{4} &= p + 3 \\
7p &= 4(p+3) \\
7p &= 4p + 12 \\
7p-4p &= 12 \\
3p &= 12 \\
p &= 4
\end{align*}\]

\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{2x}{3} &= 2x - 12 \\
2x &= 3(2x-12) \\
2x &= 6x - 36 \\
2x-6x &= -36 \\
-4x &= -36 \\
x &= 9
\end{align*}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding
Solve these equations:

\(\dfrac{3x}{2} = x + 1\)
\(2d+6 = \dfrac{8d}{3}\)
\(\dfrac{4t}{5} = 2t - 6\)
\(\dfrac{7a}{8} = 2a\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(\dfrac{3x}{2} = x + 1 \Rightarrow x=2\)
\(2d+6 = \dfrac{8d}{3} \Rightarrow d=9\)
\(\dfrac{4t}{5} = 2t - 6 \Rightarrow t=5\)
\(\dfrac{7a}{8} = 2a \Rightarrow a=0\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Comparing Methods
Solve: \[
\dfrac{x}{3} + 4 = x + 1
\]


Subtract first:
\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{x}{3} + 4 &= x + 1 \\
\dfrac{x}{3} &= x - 3 \\
x &= 3(x-3) \\
x &= 3x - 9 \\
0 &= 2x - 9 \\
9 &= 2x \\
\dfrac{9}{2} &= x
\end{align*}\]

Multiply first:
\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{x}{3} + 4 &= x + 1 \\
3 \times (\dfrac{x}{3} + 4) &= 3 \times (x + 1) \\
x + 12 &= 3x + 3 \\
12 &= 2x + 3 \\
9 &= 2x \\
\dfrac{9}{2} &= x
\end{align*}\]



\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{x}{3} + 4 &= x + 1 \\
x + 12 &= 3x + 3 \\
\end{align*}\]






Warning



Remember, when you multiply both sides, you must multiply every term. A very common error in this question is to forget to multiply the 4 by 3.

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding
Solve these equations:

\(\dfrac{a}{2} + 3 = a + 1\)
\(\dfrac{3e}{4} - 1 = e + 2\)
\(\dfrac{3p}{5} + 6 = 2p - 3\)
\(7w - 3 = \dfrac{2w}{3} - 4\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(\dfrac{a}{2} + 3 = a + 1 \Rightarrow a = 4\)
\(\dfrac{3e}{4} - 1 = e + 2 \Rightarrow e = -12\)
\(\dfrac{3p}{5} + 6 = 2p - 3 \Rightarrow p = \dfrac{45}{7}\)
\(7w - 3 = \dfrac{2w}{3} - 4 \Rightarrow w = -\dfrac{3}{19}\)

title: Linear Equations
section: Example: Equations with Fractions on Both Sides
text:
Example: Equations with Fractions on Both Sides
When there are fractions on both sides, you can multiply by both denominators at once, or the lowest common multiple of both denominators if they have a common factor.


\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{4y-3}{4} &= \dfrac{2y-4}{5} \\
5(4y-3) &= 4(2y-4) \\
20y - 15 &= 8y - 16 \\
20y - 8y &= -16 + 15 \\
12y &= -1 \\
y &= -\dfrac{1}{12}
\end{align*}\]

\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{3x+5}{3} &= \dfrac{x-1}{5} \\
5(3x+5) &= 3(x-1) \\
15x + 25 &= 3x - 3 \\
15x - 3x &= -3 -25 \\
12x &= -28 \\
x &= -\dfrac{7}{3}
\end{align*}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding
Solve these equations:

\(\dfrac{h+1}{2} = h - 5\)
\(2m+3 = \dfrac{3m+2}{4}\)
\(\dfrac{2x+3}{5} = \dfrac{3x+2}{3}\)
\(\dfrac{4t-2}{3} = \dfrac{5t-2}{5}\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(\dfrac{h+1}{2} = h - 5 \Rightarrow h = 11\)
\(2m+3 = \dfrac{3m+2}{4} \Rightarrow m = -2\)
\(\dfrac{2x+3}{5} = \dfrac{3x+2}{3} \Rightarrow x = -\dfrac{1}{9}\)
\(\dfrac{4t-2}{3} = \dfrac{5t-2}{5} \Rightarrow t = \dfrac{4}{5}\)

title: Linear Equations
section: Example: Equations with the Unknown on the Denominator
text:
Example: Equations with the Unknown on the Denominator
In these cases, we still begin by multiplying both sides by the denominator.


\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{3e+2}{e-4} &= 5 \\
3e+2 &= 5(e-4) \\
3e+2 &= 5e - 20 \\
2 &= 2e - 20 \\
22 &= 2e \\
11 &= e
\end{align*}\]

\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{7p-2}{3p+2} &= 2 \\
7p-2 &= 2(3p+2) \\
7p-2 &= 6p + 4 \\
7p-6p &= 4 + 2 \\
p &= 6
\end{align*}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding
Solve these equations:

\(\dfrac{x+5}{3x} = 4\)
\(\dfrac{7y+2}{6y} = \dfrac{2}{3}\)
\(\dfrac{5t+4}{t+5} = 3\)
\(\dfrac{2x+5}{3x+2} = 3\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(\dfrac{x+5}{3x} = 4 \Rightarrow x = \dfrac{5}{11}\)
\(\dfrac{7y+2}{6y} = \dfrac{2}{3} \Rightarrow y = -\dfrac{2}{3}\)
\(\dfrac{5t+4}{t+5} = 3 \Rightarrow t = \dfrac{11}{2}\)
\(\dfrac{2x+5}{3x+2} = 3 \Rightarrow x = -\dfrac{1}{7}\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding
Solve these equations:

\(\dfrac{x+5}{3x} = 4\)
\(\dfrac{7y+2}{6y} = \dfrac{2}{3}\)
\(\dfrac{5t+4}{t+5} = 3\)
\(\dfrac{2x+5}{3x+2} = 3\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(\dfrac{x+5}{3x} = 4 \Rightarrow x = \dfrac{5}{11}\)
\(\dfrac{7y+2}{6y} = \dfrac{2}{3} \Rightarrow y = -\dfrac{2}{3}\)
\(\dfrac{5t+4}{t+5} = 3 \Rightarrow t = \dfrac{11}{2}\)
\(\dfrac{2x+5}{3x+2} = 3 \Rightarrow x = -\dfrac{1}{7}\)

title: Linear Equations
section: Example: When the Denominators have a Common Factor
text:
Example: When the Denominators have a Common Factor
To solve these questions, we first identify the lowest common multiple of the two denominators, and then multiply both sides by this.


\[
\dfrac{5}{3a} + \dfrac{2}{5a} = 3
\]
Find the LCD: \(15a\)
\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{5}{3a} + \dfrac{2}{5a} &= 3 \\
15a \times (\dfrac{5}{3a} + \dfrac{2}{5a}) &= 15a \times 3 \\
25 + 6 &= 45a \\
45a &= 31 \\
a &= \dfrac{31}{45}
\end{align*}\]

\[
\dfrac{5}{6b} - \dfrac{7}{15b} = \dfrac{1}{2}
\] Find the LCD: \(30b\)
\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{5}{6b} - \dfrac{7}{15b} &= \dfrac{1}{2} \\
5 \times 5 - 7 \times 2 &= \dfrac{1}{2} \times 30b \\
25 - 14 &= 15b \\
15b &= 11 \\
b &= \dfrac{11}{15}
\end{align*}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding
Solve these equations:

\(\dfrac{a}{3} + \dfrac{2}{3} = 7\)
\(\dfrac{b}{2} - \dfrac{b}{8} = 9\)
\(\dfrac{5}{t} + \dfrac{1}{t} = 3\)
\(\dfrac{2}{3w} - \dfrac{1}{9w} = 15\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(\dfrac{a}{3} + \dfrac{2}{3} = 7 \Rightarrow a = 19\)
\(\dfrac{b}{2} - \dfrac{b}{8} = 9 \Rightarrow b = 24\)
\(\dfrac{5}{t} + \dfrac{1}{t} = 3 \Rightarrow t = 2\)
\(\dfrac{2}{3w} - \dfrac{1}{9w} = 15 \Rightarrow w = 27\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Fractions Leading to Brackets
In questions where there is more than one term within the numerator or denominator, you need to remember that there are effectively ‘invisible brackets’. As before, we multiply by the lowest common multiple of the denominators.
\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{k-12}{4} + \dfrac{2k+1}{2} &= k - 2 \\
(k-12) \div 4 + (2k+1) \div 2 &= k - 2 \\
k - 12 + 2(2k+1) &= 4(k-2) \\
k - 12 + 4k + 2 &= 4k - 8 \\
5k - 10 &= 4k - 8 \\
5k - 4k &= -8 + 10 \\
k &= 2 \\
\end{align*}\]

\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{5p+3}{2} - \dfrac{3p+6}{3} &= 2p - 3 \\
(5p+3) \div 2 - (3p+6) \div 3 &= 2p - 3 \\
3(5p+3) - 2(3p+6) &= 12p - 18 \\
15p + 9 - 6p - 12 &= 12p - 18 \\
9p - 3 &= 12p - 18 \\
-3 + 18 &= 12p - 9p \\
15 &= 3p \\
p &= 5
\end{align*}\]

April has twice as many chocolates as Ben.

\[

\]

\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding
Solve the following:

A chair costs £\(c\) and a table costs 4 times as much. What is the cost of 4 chairs?
A chair costs £\(c\) and a table costs 4 times as much. What is the cost of 3 tables?

title: Linear Equations
section: Example: Forming & Solving Equations from Context
text:
Example: Forming & Solving Equations from Context
I think of a number, I divide it by 5, then add 9 to it. The result is 42. Let the number be \(m\). This gives:
\[
\dfrac{m}{5} + 9 = 42
\]
To solve:
\[\begin{align*}
\dfrac{m}{5} + 9 &= 42 \\
\dfrac{m}{5} &= 42 - 9 \\
\dfrac{m}{5} &= 33 \\
m &= 33 \times 5 \\
m &= 165
\end{align*}\]

I think of a number, I subtract 3 from it, then I triple it. The result is 60. Let the number be \(n\). This gives:
\[
3(n - 3) = 60
\]
To solve:
\[\begin{align*}
3(n - 3) &= 60 \\
n - 3 &= 60 \div 3 \\
n - 3 &= 20 \\
n &= 20 + 3 \\
n &= 23
\end{align*}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding
Form and solve an equation from each of these examples.

I think of a number, I then add 5 to it. The result is 12.
I think of a number, I then multiply it by 6. The result is 54.
I think of a number, I double it, then add 3. The result is 19.
I think of a number, I divide it by 3, and then subtract 11 from it. The result is \(-2\).
I think of a number, I add 3 to it, then I double it. The result is 19.

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(a + 5 = 12 \;\Rightarrow\; a = 7\)
\(6b = 54 \;\Rightarrow\; b = 9\)
\(2c + 3 = 19 \;\Rightarrow\; 2c = 16 \;\Rightarrow\; c = 8\)
\(\dfrac{d}{3} - 11 = -2 \;\Rightarrow\; \dfrac{d}{3} = 9 \;\Rightarrow\; d = 27\)
\(2(e + 3) = 19 \;\Rightarrow\; e = \dfrac{13}{2}\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: More Advanced Forming

John has \(x\) sweets.

Henri has 4 more sweets than John.

Sam has 2 times as many sweets as John.
Altogether they have 32 sweets. Find how many sweets John has.

Let John’s number of sweets be \(x\). Then:

John: \(x\)

Henri: \(x + 4\)

Sam: \(2x\)

Since the total is 32, we form:
\[
x + (x + 4) + 2x = 32
\]

Combine like terms and solve:
\[\begin{align*}
4x + 4 &= 32 \\
4x &= 32 - 4 \\
4x &= 28 \\
x &= 28 \div 4 \\
x &= 7
\end{align*}\]
Therefore, John has 7 sweets.

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding
Peter has \(y\) loaves.
Andrew has 2 fewer loaves than Peter.
John has 4 times as many loaves as Peter.
Altogether they have 16 loaves. Find how many loaves Andrew has.

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers
Let:

Peter: \(y\)

Andrew: \(y - 2\)

John: \(4y\)

Since the total is 16: \[
y + (y - 2) + 4y = 16
\]

Combine like terms and solve: \[\begin{align*}
6y - 2 &= 16 \\
6y &= 16 + 2 \\
6y &= 18 \\
y &= 3
\end{align*}\]
As Andrew has \(y - 2\) loaves: \[
3 - 2 = 1
\]
Therefore, Andrew has 1 loaf.






Be careful



The value of \(y\) is not the final answer.

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Simplify algebraic expressions
Expand brackets
Solve equations in which the unknown appears on both sides

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Basic Principles
Algebra uses letters, often \(x\), to stand for numbers. Algebraic expressions can be treated in the same way as number expressions.

\(x + 3\) means “add three to the unknown number.”

\(3x\) means “3 times the unknown number.”

\(x^2\) means “square the unknown number.”

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Example: Combining Like Terms
\[
a + 3ab - 4ba = a - ab
\]






Note



Note: \(ab = ba\), so \(3ab\) and \(-4ba\) are like terms.


\[
3p^3 + 2p^2 - 2p^3 + 5p^2 = (3p^3 - 2p^3) + (2p^2 + 5p^2) = p^3 + 7p^2
\]

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Example: Multiplying Algebraic Terms
\[
4r \times 5t = 20rt
\]
\[
(3b)^2 \times 3b = 9b^2 \times 3b = 27b^3
\]






Tip




The multiplication sign is often not included between letters, e.g. \(3ab\) means \(3 \times a \times b\)
When multiplying, add like powers: \(3a^2b \times 2a^5b^4 = 6a^8b^5\). (Think of \(a\) as \(a^1\)).

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Example: Expanding Brackets
Video: Expanding Single Brackets
\[
2(3 + x) = 2 \times 3 + 2 \times x = 6 + 2x
\]






Tip




Multiply each term inside by the outside term.
The multiplication sign is usually left out: \(3(x+y)\) means \(3 \times (x + y) = 3 \times x + 3 \times y = 3x + 3y\)
When multiplying, the number 1 is usually left out: \(-(2x+3)\) means \(-1 \times (2x+3) = (-1) \times (2x) + (-1) \times 3 = -2x + 3\)










Warning



Be very careful with negative signs outside a bracket.


\[
-2 \times (a-3) = (-2) \times a + (-2) \times (-3) = -2a + 6
\]

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Example: Expanding with Indices
Expand \(5x^2(12x^3 + 4x^5)\)
\[
5x^2 \times 12x^3 + 5x^2 \times 4x^5 = 60x^5 + 20x^7
\]

title: Expanding Brackets
text:

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Example: Expanding Double Brackets
Video: Expanding Double Brackets
To expand \((x + 3)(x + 2)\), you can use the grid method. \[
\begin{array}{c|cc}
    & x & +2 \\ \hline
x   & x^2 & 2x \\
+3   & 3x  & 6
\end{array}
\]
Summing the terms on the inside and simplifying gives:
\[
x^2 + 3x + 2x +6 = x^2 + 5x + 6
\]

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Example: Squared Bracket
A squared bracket is simply the same bracket twice. For example to expand \[
(2x+3)^2
\] the grid method is: \[
\begin{array}{c|cc}
    & 2x & +3 \\ \hline
2x  & 4x^2  & 6x \\
+3  & 6x    & 9
\end{array}
\]
Adding the terms on the inside and simplifying gives
\[
4x^2 + 12x + 9
\]

Expand and simplify \((x^2 + 6x - 3)(x-4)\)

\begin{array}{c|cc}
     & x      & -4      \\ \hline
x^2  & x^3    & -4x^2   \\
6x   & 6x^2   & -24x    \\
-3   & -3x    & 12
\end{array}

=\ &x^3 + 2x^2 - 27x + 12

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Example: Triple Brackets
Video: Expanding Triple Brackets
A three‐bracket expansion such as \((x+1)(x-3)(x+2)\) can be done in two grid‐method steps. First, expand \((x-3)(x+2)\):
\[
\begin{array}{c|cc}
& x   & +2 \\ \hline
x  & x^2 & 2x  \\
-3 & -3x & -6
\end{array}
\]
This gives a result of
\[
x^2 - x - 6
\]

Then expand \((x+1)(x^2 - x - 6)\) with a \(2 \times 3\) grid:
\[
\begin{array}{c|ccc}
& x^2    & -x     & -6   \\ \hline
x     & x^3    & -x^2   & -6x  \\
+1    & x^2    & -x     & -6
\end{array}
\]
So altogether \((x+1)(x-3)(x+2)=x^3-7x-6\)






Tip



The order you multiply the brackets does not matter.

title: Fractions
text:
Method Comparison
To calculate \(\dfrac{1}{6} + \dfrac{3}{4}\), there are two methods


Multiply denominators \[
\dfrac{4}{24} + \dfrac{18}{24} = \dfrac{22}{24} = \dfrac{11}{12}
\]

Lowest common multiple \[
\dfrac{2}{12} + \dfrac{9}{12} = \dfrac{11}{12}
\]


Which method do you think is better?

text:

title: Fractions
text:
Example: Adding Mixed Numbers
Key skill video
Calculate: \(1\dfrac{1}{4} + 3\dfrac{1}{12}\)


Improper fractions \[
1\dfrac{1}{4} = \dfrac{5}{4}
\] \[
3\dfrac{1}{12} = \dfrac{37}{12}
\] \[
\dfrac{5}{4} = \dfrac{5\times 3}{4\times 3} = \dfrac{15}{12}
\] Add: \[
\dfrac{15}{12} + \dfrac{37}{12} = \dfrac{52}{12} = 4\dfrac{4}{12} = 4\dfrac{1}{3}
\]

Partitioning
Integers: \[
1 + 3 = 4
\] Fractions: \[
\dfrac{1}{4} + \dfrac{1}{12} = \dfrac{3}{12} + \dfrac{1}{12} = \dfrac{4}{12} = \dfrac{1}{3}
\]
Combine: \[
4 + \dfrac{1}{3} = 4\dfrac{1}{3}
\]

title: Fractions
text:
Test Your Understanding
Calculate, giving your answer as a mixed number in its simplest form:

\(2\dfrac{4}{7} + 5\dfrac{2}{3}\)
\(6\dfrac{2}{5} + 3\dfrac{9}{10}\)
\(8\dfrac{7}{8} + 4\dfrac{5}{6}\)
\(7\dfrac{7}{9} + 3\dfrac{11}{18}\)
\(12\dfrac{6}{11} + 1\dfrac{5}{8}\)

title: Fractions
text:
Example: Subtracting Mixed Numbers
Key skill video
Calculate: \(7\dfrac{1}{12} - 5\dfrac{3}{4}\) Give your answer as a mixed number in its simplest form.


Improper Fractions
\[
7\dfrac{1}{12} = \dfrac{7\times12 + 1}{12} = \dfrac{85}{12}
\] \[
5\dfrac{3}{4} = \dfrac{5\times4 + 3}{4} = \dfrac{23}{4} = \dfrac{69}{12}
\]
Subtract: \[
\dfrac{85}{12} - \dfrac{69}{12} = \dfrac{16}{12} = 1\dfrac{4}{12} = 1\dfrac{1}{3}
\]

Partitioning
Split into whole and fractional parts:
Integers: \[7 - 5 = 2\]
Fractions: \[
\dfrac{1}{12} - \dfrac{3}{4}= \dfrac{1}{12} - \dfrac{9}{12} = -\dfrac{8}{12} = -\dfrac{2}{3}
\]
Combine: \[
2 + \bigl(-\dfrac{2}{3}\bigr) = 1\dfrac{1}{3}
\]

title: Fractions
text:
Example: Multiplying Fractions
Key skill video
\[
\dfrac{4}{9} \times \dfrac{3}{5} = \dfrac{4 \times 3}{9 \times 5} = \dfrac{12}{45} = \dfrac{4}{15}
\] You can cancel after you multiply, but it’s usually better to cancel before: \[
\dfrac{12}{25} \times \dfrac{20}{21} = \dfrac{\boxed{3} \times 4}{5 \times \boxed{5}} \times \dfrac{\boxed{5} \times 4}{\boxed{3} \times 7} = \dfrac{4}{5} \times \dfrac{4}{7} = \dfrac{16}{35}
\]

title: Fractions
section: Example: Powers and Roots of Fractions
text:
Example: Powers and Roots of Fractions
Squaring means multiplying by itself, so to square a fraction you simply square the numerator and square the denominator: \[\left(\dfrac{3}{7}\right)^2 = \dfrac{3}{7} \times \dfrac{3}{7} = \dfrac{3 \times 3}{7 \times 7} = \dfrac{9}{49}\]
The same goes for cubing: \[\left(\dfrac{2}{5}\right)^3 = \dfrac{2}{5} \times \dfrac{2}{5} \times \dfrac{2}{5} = \dfrac{8}{125}\]
To square root, you square root the numerator and square root the denominator: \[\sqrt{\dfrac{4}{25}} = \dfrac{\sqrt{4}}{\sqrt{25}} = \dfrac{2}{5}\]

title: Fractions
text:
Test Your Understanding
Calculate:

\(\left(\dfrac{1}{6}\right)^2\)
\(\left(\dfrac{2}{5}\right)^2\)
\(\left(-\dfrac{7}{12}\right)^2\)
\(\left(\dfrac{3}{4}\right)^3\)
\(\left(\dfrac{1}{10}\right)^5\)
\(\sqrt{\dfrac{81}{121}}\)

title: Fractions
text:
Answers

\(\left(\dfrac{1}{6}\right)^2 = \dfrac{1}{36}\)
\(\left(\dfrac{2}{5}\right)^2 = \dfrac{4}{25}\)
\(\left(-\dfrac{7}{12}\right)^2 = \dfrac{49}{144}\)
\(\left(\dfrac{3}{4}\right)^3 = \dfrac{27}{64}\)
\(\left(\dfrac{1}{10}\right)^5 = \dfrac{1}{100000}\)
\(\sqrt{\dfrac{81}{121}} = \dfrac{9}{11}\)

title: Fractions
text:
Example: Multiplying Mixed Numbers
Key skill video
To multiply mixed numbers, first convert them to improper fractions: \[
4\dfrac{2}{5} \times 1\dfrac{7}{8} = \dfrac{22}{5} \times \dfrac{15}{8} = \dfrac{11 \times \boxed{2}}{\boxed{5}} \times \dfrac{3 \times \boxed{5}}{\boxed{2} \times 4} = \dfrac{11 \times 3}{4} = \dfrac{33}{4}
\]

title: Fractions
section: Example: Dividing by a Unit Fraction
text:
Example: Dividing by a Unit Fraction
Consider a calculation like \(5 \div \dfrac{1}{3}\)
This means How many thirds go into five?
. . .
We know the answer is 15, but how can we explain the method?
. . .
We can explain this in terms of multiplying by the reciprocal: \[
5 \div \dfrac{1}{3} = 5 \times \dfrac{3}{1} = 15
\]

title: Fractions
text:
Example: Dividing by Other Fractions
Key skill video
To divide by other fractions, we can use the same technique: multiplying by the reciprocal: \[
4 \div \dfrac{2}{5} = 4 \times \dfrac{5}{2} = \dfrac{4}{1} \times \dfrac{5}{2} = \dfrac{20}{2} = 10
\] Don’t forget to continue to cancel before multiplying if you can: \[
\dfrac{5}{12} \div \dfrac{3}{8} = \dfrac{5}{12} \times \dfrac{8}{3} = \dfrac{5}{\boxed{4} \times 3} \times \dfrac{\boxed{4} \times 2}{3} = \dfrac{10}{9} = 1\dfrac{1}{9}
\]

Test Your Understanding

\(\dfrac{4}{9} \div \dfrac{7}{5}\)
\(\dfrac{2}{7} \div \dfrac{3}{11}\)
\(\dfrac{6}{7} \div \dfrac{3}{10}\)

title: Fractions
text:
Example: Dividing Mixed Numbers
Like with multiplying mixed numbers, the first step in dividing mixed numbers is to convert them to improper fractions: \[
1\dfrac{3}{7} \div \dfrac{1}{5} = \dfrac{10}{7} \div \dfrac{1}{5} = \dfrac{10}{7} \times \dfrac{5}{1} = \dfrac{50}{7} = 7\dfrac{1}{7}
\]
\[
1\dfrac{5}{9} \div 2\dfrac{4}{5} = \dfrac{14}{9} \div \dfrac{14}{5} = \dfrac{14}{9} \times \dfrac{5}{14} = \dfrac{1}{9} \times \dfrac{5}{1} = \dfrac{5}{9}
\]

title: Straight Line Graphs
text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Points that define the main segment (slope 3)
A = (1, 0)   # bottom point
B = (3, 6)   # top point
C = (2, 3)   # mid-step point (1 across, 3 up)

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(4, 8))

# Main line segment
ax.plot([A[0], B[0]], [A[1], B[1]], linewidth=3, color="black")

# Arrow at the top end of the line
ax.annotate(
    "",
    xy=B, xytext=(B[0] - 0.05, B[1] - 0.3),
    arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle="->", linewidth=3, color="black")
)

# --- Small rise/run rectangle (A→C) ---
# horizontal bottom
ax.plot([A[0], C[0]], [A[1], A[1]], linestyle="--", linewidth=2, color="green")
# vertical right
ax.plot([C[0], C[0]], [A[1], C[1]], linestyle="--", linewidth=2, color="green")

# double-headed arrows
ax.annotate("", xy=(C[0], A[1]), xytext=(A[0], A[1]),
            arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle="<->", color="green"))
ax.annotate("", xy=(C[0], C[1]), xytext=(C[0], A[1]),
            arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle="<->", color="teal"))

# --- Large rise/run rectangle (A→B) ---
ax.plot([A[0], B[0]], [A[1], A[1]], linestyle="--", linewidth=2, color="green")
ax.plot([B[0], B[0]], [A[1], B[1]], linestyle="--", linewidth=2, color="teal")

ax.annotate("", xy=(B[0], A[1]), xytext=(A[0], A[1]),
            arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle="<->", color="green"))
ax.annotate("", xy=(B[0], B[1]), xytext=(B[0], A[1]),
            arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle="<->", color="teal"))

# Midline horizontal guide at y=3
ax.plot([A[0], B[0]], [C[1], C[1]], linestyle="--", linewidth=2, color="teal")

# Labels
ax.text((A[0]+C[0])/2, A[1]-0.35, "1", ha="center", va="top", fontsize=14, color="green")
ax.text(C[0]+0.15, (A[1]+C[1])/2, "3", ha="left", va="center", fontsize=14, color="teal")
ax.text((A[0]+B[0])/2, A[1]-0.35, "2", ha="center", va="top", fontsize=14, color="green")
ax.text(B[0]+0.15, (A[1]+B[1])/2, "6", ha="left", va="center", fontsize=14, color="teal")

# Axes styling to resemble squared paper
ax.set_xlim(0, 4)
ax.set_ylim(-1, 8)
ax.set_aspect('equal', adjustable='box')
ax.set_xticks(range(0, 5))
ax.set_yticks(range(-1, 9))
ax.grid(True, which='both', linewidth=0.8, alpha=0.5)

# Hide spines and ticks for a clean look
for spine in ["top", "right", "left", "bottom"]:
    ax.spines[spine].set_visible(False)
ax.tick_params(left=False, bottom=False, labelleft=False, labelbottom=False)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Points that define the main segment (slope 3)

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(4, 8))

ax.text(C[0]+0.15, (A[1]+C[1])/2, "3", ha="left", va="center", fontsize=14, color="teal")
ax.text((A[0]+B[0])/2, A[1]-0.35, "2", ha="center", va="top", fontsize=14, color="green")
ax.text(B[0]+0.15, (A[1]+B[1])/2, "6", ha="left", va="center", fontsize=14, color="teal")

# Axes styling to resemble squared paper
ax.set_xlim(0, 4)
ax.set_ylim(-1, 8)
ax.set_aspect('equal', adjustable='box')
ax.set_xticks(range(0, 5))
ax.set_yticks(range(-1, 9))
ax.grid(True, which='both', linewidth=0.8, alpha=0.5)

# Hide spines and ticks for a clean look
for spine in ["top", "right", "left", "bottom"]:
    ax.spines[spine].set_visible(False)
ax.tick_params(left=False, bottom=False, labelleft=False, labelbottom=False)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

title: Rounding and Estimation
text:
Question: Round 3.44 to 1 decimal place.
When rounding to a given number of decimal places, we are always rounding to a number with at most this number of decimal places.
. . .
In this case, that means the answer must have 1 decimal place. What are the possible answers therefore?
. . .
It has to be one of the two closest numbers with 1 decimal place: \[
3.4 < 3.44 < 3.5
\] . . .
The first decimal place will either round up to 5 or down to 4. This is called the rounding digit.
. . .
How we decide depends on the following digit, which we call the deciding digit.
. . .
\[3.(4)\underline{4} \longrightarrow 3.4\]
Here we circle the rounding digit and underline the deciding digit. When the deciding digit is less than 5, we round down.

title: Rounding and Estimation
text:
Question: Round 3.44 to 1 decimal place.
When rounding to a given number of decimal places, we are always rounding to a number with at most this number of decimal places.
. . .
In this case, that means the answer must have 1 decimal place. What are the possible answers therefore?
. . .
It has to be one of the two closest numbers with 1 decimal place: \[
3.4 < 3.44 < 3.5
\] . . .
The first decimal place will either round up to 5 or down to 4. This is called the rounding digit.
. . .
How we decide depends on the following digit, which we call the deciding digit.
. . .
\[3.(4)\underline{4} \longrightarrow 3.4\]
Here we circle the rounding digit and underline the deciding digit. When the deciding digit is less than 5, we round down.

title: Rounding and Estimation
section: Example: Rounding to More Decimal Places
text:
Example: Rounding to More Decimal Places
When we round to a particular number of decimal places we just need to circle the corresponding rounding digit, and then we deciding digit is always the one immediately following.
Round 4.650712 to 4 decimal places:
\[4.650(7)\underline{1}2 \longrightarrow 4.6507\]

title: Rounding and Estimation
text:
Significant Figures
In a number like 27,593, each digit is worth a different amount:

The 2 is worth 20,000
The 7 is worth 7,000
The 5 is worth 500
The 9 is worth 90
The 3 is worth 3

The first significant figure is 2, the second is 7 etc.

In a number like 4.678,

The 4 is worth 4
The 6 is worth \(\dfrac{6}{10}\)
The 7 is worth \(\dfrac{7}{100}\)
The 8 is worth \(\dfrac{8}{1000}\)

title: Rounding and Estimation
text:
Example: Rounding to 1 Significant Figure
When rounding with siginificant figures, the way we round depends on the size of the number.
Round 647 to 1 s.f. \[
(6)\underline{4}7 \longrightarrow 600
\]
In this case, we are rounding to the nearest hundred because the first significant figure is 6, which has a place value of 600.

Round 0.27 to 1 s.f. \[
0.(2)\underline{7} \longrightarrow 0.3
\]
In this case, we are rounding to the nearest tenth (1 d.p.) because the first significant figure is 2, which is worth 2 tenths.

Round 6,378,527 to 1 s.f. \[
(6)\underline{3}78527
\]
In this case we are rounding to the nearest one million because the first significant figure is 6, which is worth 6 million.

title: Rounding and Estimation
section: Example: More than One Significant Figure
text:
Example: More than One Significant Figure
Round 647 to 2 s.f. \[
6(4)\underline{7} \longrightarrow 650
\]
Round 0.5472 to 3 s.f. \[
0.54(7)\underline{2} \longrightarrow 0.547
\]






Note



Initial zeros do not count as significant figures because they merely show the place value of the other digits. Zeros between non-zero digits do count, however.
